pros: Flexibility, Great colleagues, Holidays and vacations
cons: None that I can share

pros: Excellent work culture Lots to learn and grow
cons: Need to continue to diversify funding streams.

review_title: Great place to work if you love causes
pros: Wonderful multicultural environment and great learning opportunity
cons: Funding but great opportunities can be improved through a better resource mobilization strategy

job_title: Senior M&E Expert in New Delhi
pros: employee friendly policies, good working environment, high quality of professionalism, HR team very supportive and liberal HR policies,
cons: Finance team is very weak and very unprofessional,

review_title: US-based employee insurance coverage ironically excludes all  fertility treatment
pros: Strong record of providing high-quality programming around the world to advance the sexual and reproductive health of all.
cons: Decent healthcare benefits with the critical, almost unforgivable exception of fertility/infertility treatment for its US-based employees. This is ironic (and exceptionally frustrating), given that EngenderHealth is a sexual and reproductive health and rights organization intending to ensure women are able to exercise their agency and have the capacity to determine their own reproductive futures. This glaring gap in health insurance coverage for the organization's own US-based employees is extraordinarily disappointing and worth noting to prospective future employees.

pros: Provide an avenue to do a global good
cons: Challenges of power dynamics like any other Northern NGO is prevalent. Though the management is trying to solve that

pros: Was given lots of responsibility
cons: A bit hectic at times but that can be said for all NGOs

job_title: Medical Doctor and Manager in Bahir Dar
pros:
Motivated , friendly staff , focused on deliverables only .
 Its priorities are inclusive and timely updated .
 It cares about the employee .
cons: Did not bring more donors to Ethiopia .

pros: Builds capacities of staff, conducive working environment
cons: don't provide financial support for self career development

review_title: My journey at a glance: One of the best organization to work with
pros:
Good salary structure
Clear HR guideline
Staff centric policies
cons: Being a non MBBS employee and even with higher education and experience the growth becomes stagnant.

pros: Excellent and progressive top management team
cons: Need continued focus on fund raising and new business development

pros: It was a good place to start
cons: No comment at this time

pros: All international staff, based on the Home Office, are new. In the event of a difficulty, we work together to find a solution. We work as a team.
cons: Not everyone is run in the same way. There are favors that are done at least deserving.

pros: Pay is good. Good benefits. Great people.
cons: None that I know of .

review_title: competitive salaries compared to market, good work culture but no long term vision
pros: good work culture, competitive salaries
cons: Very short term projects, should try for continuation or other projects well in advance.

pros: CEO with a great vision
cons: Stifling control from HQ to country offices. Management actions conflicts with what they say

pros: Great benefits, concerned about the well-being of employees
cons: High workload, has some resource challenges.

pros: Good Work environment and good policy for employee
cons: Experience person for training and Management team

pros:
Good Policy 
Good Salary 
Good Staff
cons: Good organization, No negative Fed back.

pros: I really tried to write something positive. I thought about it for days and days.  I could not come up with anything except that some of my colleagues are great to work with at Engenderhealth.
cons: It is with utter sadness that I write about the demise of this great organization.  At one time this was really a great place to work, we put in blood, sweat and tears upholding our mission and vision.  And, we were GLAD to pour out those blood, sweat and tears for our beloved Engenderhealth.  Now, this place is almost a shell of its former self.  We move like zombies through the day, just going through the motions while the "executive leaders" - I just laughed so hard at that phrase that I snorted tea!  Anyway, we move like zombies waiting for someone to come and rescue us, give us a purpose, give us an understanding of who we are now, where we are going and very simply...WHAT'S THE PLAN CEO?  We are simply collecting paychecks, which makes you feel guilty.  The "leaders" of the organization are largely absence, or (lightbulb), are the “leaders” just collecting paychecks too?  As other reviewers wrote, which is true stuff by the way, (1) we have new leaders that we have never met,  this is especially true of our head of HR we have yet to meet him, he’s based overseas. (2) we don’t understand our organizational focus (3) the “leadership” team is being stacked with former Marie Stopes employees; read: don’t bother applying if you did not work at Marie Stopes.  The purpose is gone, the mission is gone, the motivation is gone.

pros: Long history, respected thought leader in SRH field, provides professional development opportunities for staff, collaborative partner.  Currently making bold and brave changes in response to changing external environment in order to remain relevant.
cons: Can be better at marketing organization's great work.

pros: It used to be a well recognized and respected organization, with excellent, family friendly work environment. Now, pros are hard to identify
cons: Transitions are always accompanied by challenges and a few ruffled feathers but the low morale and discontent at the organization is not just the normal byproduct of a CEO transition. It is indicative of the incompetence of the senior leadership team, the disregard shown by the senior leadership team, particularly the CEO, to the organizational and staff needs, it is the hypocrisy of caring for the woman and girls around the world while pulling back of benefits and flexibility that the parents at the organization depend on at will. The CEO is inexperienced, has displayed a blatant disregard for the employees, and has shown an embarrassing lack of depth of thinking. She has selectively pushed out employees that have dared to object to the policies and practice that she is implementing and put together a team that agrees with her decisions, no matter how ridiculous. It appears from the outside that the senior leadership team is a group of inexperienced amateurs who have no idea what you do and so are creating damaging rules and policies just to display authority and get control. It is an environment that will and is driving out what little talent is left.

job_title: Vice President, Global Communications & Marketing in Washington, DC
pros:
-	Committed to striving for equality in and through sexual and reproductive health and rights programming
-	Great teams in 10+ countries around the world are delivering high-quality programmatic work with results
-	Excellent partnerships with national governments, implementing partners, and donors
-	A solid legacy on which to continue building
-	Headquarters (DC) staff is mostly new and newly energized
-	Teams are excited about our updated theory of change and strategic plan
-	CEO is creative, well-respected inside and outside of the organization, committed to excellence, and inspirational
cons:
-	Working internationally in sexual and reproductive health and rights is particularly challenging at this time. 
-	The organization went through some major transitions in recent years, and as a result is currently in a mode of building/improving on a multitude of systems and processes at headquarters. I actually see this as a fun challenge and a huge opportunity, but for anyone who does not enjoy change and everything that entails, these challenges may be experienced as a con.

pros: good work culture good work culture
cons: as per there no cons

pros: EngenderHealth does great work and has many employees that are extremely hard working and intelligent individuals. They also have a good benefits package.
cons: The organizations is slowing ripping apart at the seams. Unsustainable talent retention due to dependence on grant funding for specific projects. Dying donor base. Mismanagement. Employees lacking innovation or vision and dinosaurs sticking around that continue to do things the same way for decades. Dreary atmosphere.  There is no communication between the different department, i.e. the communications team doesn't know what the program team is doing and vice versa. People are quitting every week and it will be surprising if this organization is able to pull through. All non-profits are suffering in this field and this economy but EH seems to be hit especially hard. Changes need to be made. The external relations team has an exciting marketing campaign but it's taking years to launch - it may be too late.

pros: As someone who has been here for a while and worked here through this period of transition, I can say, that EngenderHealth is a long-standing organization that works across countries to live up to its vision and mission. This place attracts committed, driven and talented people. Everyone here feels passionately for the area of work and strives to deliver change at the grassroots. Good work by staff is recognized and valued. At a recent event, the management recognized and felicitated staff for their exceptional work. Employee recognition is a terrific way to build a positive, productive workplace. The overall packages and benefits match industry standards.
cons: A period of transition is always difficult for those in lead and for those being led. It is important to tide over this change together and emerge stronger than before.

review_title: Energy Needed to Save this Important Non-profit
pros: The values of the organization are top-notch, the Mission is central to development of societies all over the world. People have stayed with the organization for decades because of the Mission and top professionals who work in NYC and around the world.
cons: Current leadership is not aggressive enough in pursuing all opportunities that are available in our community. Strategic planning is a weakness and often the plans don't match reality of the international public health "business". Aging out of internationally recognized experts is a problem for continued growth. (dinosaurs may be old but they brought in the projects time and time again). This business is built on excellent relationships with donors - which the dinosaurs had. Work-life balance is supported. Young people have lots of room to grow if they are competent.

review_title: Let’s genuinely deal with problems, internally!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I’ve worked with EngenderHealth long enough and know this organization’s greatest assets are its passionate and talented people who at each level have demonstrated time and time again their deep support and commitment to the mission.
cons:
Unfortunately, within one year, this great asset has been disintegrating because of new Management that still thinks putting on a show however emotional, is good enough to make the glaring and painful issues dogging the morale of staff will simply disappear. 
I read the positive and hopeful review above and  couldn't help thinking that this isn't what we've been living through for almost a year. Nothing has changed. Management has done nothing to reach out…

review_title: Tyrannical CEO + Submissive Leadership Team = Recipe for Disaster
pros: Amazing benefits package. Extremely generous time off. Those staff who remain are very committed to the mission.
cons: Unfortunately, this review will likely rehash what has already been said in the many other scathing reviews recently. To start, do not be fooled by the few "positive" reviews sprinkled in from the past few months. Those are very likely made-up reviews prompted by the CEO and her ever-growing group of overpaid consultants. This is a completely rudderless organization with no known source of new funding. If you are looking for a quick cash grab and are a Marie Stopes cronie of the CEO, then by all means, come and drain this place for its last remaining pennies. But if you are looking to be associated with an up-and-coming family planning organization, avoid EngenderHealth at all costs.

review_title: Great Mission, Friendly People, Bright Future
pros:
- Incredible mission
- Friendly, passionate, down-to-earth staff
- Good leadership trying their best to improve and build up the organization despite facing hurdles due to the org's move a few years ago from NYC to DC
- A historic organization with a deep legacy of high-quality SRHR work, especially in Tanzania, India, and Ethiopia
- Good pay and benefits
- Nice office space
cons: There are still some hurdles due to the org moving its HQ from NYC to DC a few years ago and, therefore, having to essentially rebuild. Some things have become back-logged, and sometimes there is limited staff/capacity for certain tasks. Despite this, leadership and staff are doing their best to keep things moving forward, and the future of the organization looks bright (especially under the current president).

job_title: Program Associate in New York, NY
pros: As a recent hire, I have been very pleased with the onboarding process with my supervisor, other departments, and HR. My supervisor sat down with me to set goals for professional growth in addition to laying out my duties and responsibilities. The staff are very welcoming and committed to the mission of EngenderHealth. The recently remodeled office is an improved work environment.
cons: While collaborative team work is part of the job, being a motivated and independent worker is important. Due to the nature of our work (many US-based staff travel a lot and staff are located in 20+ offices) and the generous work-life policies (a major pro), it is not uncommon to be the only staff from your team in the office on a given day. Flexibility and multi-media communication are keys to succeeding here.

review_title: Needs to focus on country programs
pros: It was one of the organization worked for 75 years around the globe to improve women and men health by making better access to family planning. Great colleagues!  Liberty to work.
cons: It is good that there is a new leadership. This leadership tries to restart with a new vision. But in the meantime has lost focus into country program. Some project offices are not managed properly with lot of irregularities and mismanagement in terms of program and operations. Regional offices should be more keen to monitor what is happening in country offices. Some of the Country Mangers are exercise their power to do whatever they wants which makes bad reputation among partners.

review_title: Short term thinking yields short term results
pros: EngenderHealth's mission has the ability to reach so many people who dont have access to good health resources. The teams are very laid back and its a low pressure office environment. The benefits are pretty great for an NGO (vacation, salary, retirement).
cons: Many of the people are complacent and only willing to do the bare minimum to get by. Most of these people are on their way out and do not care what happens and many of these are the technical leadership. The CEO seems bipolar between being 'one of the team' and then making requests that do not align with the perpetuity of the company. This makes for a hostile work environment where its unclear what to expect next.

review_title: Yesterday all my troubles seem so far away
pros: My colleagues are great.  We stand united.
cons: Every time I walk into work at Engenderhealth I think of the song yesterday all my troubles seem so far away.   It seems like it was only yesterday that I LOVED MY JOB!  Today like many, many others I am looking, wishing, hoping to get away from here.  I am not going to repeat everything that has already been written on this site and many others.  What's the point? Nothing will change here.  The CEO will keep pushing her agenda.  Engenderhealth will keep on the downward spiral.  Employees will keep gathering in groups remembering the good old days.  And I, along with other employees will keep sending out resumes, wishing, hoping and looking for another job.  If you know anyone that is hiring please tell them to contact staff at Engenderhealth.

review_title: There were many success and challenges. Overall a challenging work environment.
job_title: Senior Technical Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Lots of opportunity to grow professionally and monetarily over many years while employed.
cons: It seems that those that did not work as hard but were well liked by those in leadership advanced even when they were not qualified to do so. This impacted the morale greatly. There was a culture of  owning one's work without giving credit. Hours were long and colleagues were even expected to be responsive during holidays, vacation and days off. It is not a culture for adequate work life balance.

pros:
-A strong mission that many people here are committed to
-High salary levels compared to similar organizations
-Excellent benefits that are well above the industry standard: 4 weeks of vacation time for everyone, starting year one; 35-hour work week; great 401k match; very good medical and pension programs.
cons:
-The upheaval that comes with a top management turnover
-New CEO who, yes, has made some management missteps, but is obviously dedicated to the mission and the success of the organization
-An entrenched group of nay-sayers who seem determined to spread negativity and dissatisfaction. Instead of dwelling on the missteps, it would be better for the organization, and for everyone, if they chose to be more forward-looking.

review_title: Finally, light at the end of a dark tunnel!
pros:
It is no secret that EngenderHealth has fallen on some tough times recently. There was simply too much to overcome without massive disruption to the organization. The (now former) CEO was a terrible fit, staff were/are disgruntled (I love my colleagues, though think many of them behaved in unprofessional ways), a new strategy was revealed and the organization was in the midst of a restructure and relocation. Contentious union negotiations just compounded matters for the worse. 

So with all the chaos, why is EngenderHealth still worthy of a four-star review?

Because I truly believe the choppy waters are behind the organization and there are calmer seas ahead.

I have previously lambasted the organization on this site, however, I am pleasantly surprised to see that management has made a 180 degree shift in the right direction. The interim CEO commands respect across the organization. The board has been much more actively involved. The leadership team and board have opened their doors, heard and responded favorably to staff feedback. Bad program decisions have been reversed. There is a push to become more aggressive and go for new and exciting bids. There is still A LOT of work that needs to be done to rectify the mistakes of the past, but I am cautiously optimistic the organization is in the right hands, and more importantly on the right track.
cons: It is sad that a lot of long-time staffers will be leaving at the end of April. However, I hope the leadership team see this as an opportunity to revitalize and rebuild EngenderHealth.

pros:
Long history. The organization has been around for over 70 years. 
Location of office in DC is great. 
Good amount of PTO.
cons: EngenderHealth has been in transition mode for several years and management can't seem to prioritize what it needs to fix. Morale is low. Very high turnover of staff. No clear direction of where the organization wants to go and what it will do. Some management leaders do not have the skills to manage people and need to be evaluated.

review_title: Mission-driven organization; flexible family oriented employer
pros:
generous telecommuting policy; decent salaries and benefits
global health mission with strong gender lens
well-established and respected organization
strong reputation in many countries
cons:
frequent changes of leadership at the top over last ten years has not meshed well with long term staff 
poor attraction and retention of younger tier of leaders and managers
behind the curve programmatically; slow to innovate and/or take risks that could have moved the agency forward

review_title: So sad to see this happen to once a great organization!
pros: Vacation, sick, and personal days are great.  Extremely dedicated and committed staff (excluding the executive team), and country specific staff.
cons: No leadership.  To suggest that the leadership is poor, would be to suggest that there is any leadership at all.  Poorly executed strategy, layoffs, and communication (none of which ever had the best interest of staff in mind).  Executive team members being promoted to higher positions without any explanations to staff.  Telecommuting dissolved (even though the staff met with the union reps and put together evidence-based research discussing the benefits of having this option available to staff). In addition, staff are not treated with the respect they deserve as highly accomplished subject matter experts.

review_title: Aging organization, on the decline but will come back strong in 1-2 yrs time
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Strong work all over the world with multiple country teams.  Good reputation globally and a strong relationship with USAID missions and USAID/W
cons: Aging organization.  Privileges older generation of returned peace corps volunteers who served in post-independance Africa.  As such, it is rigid to innovation, new talent, and recalcitrant against incorporation of new technologies or new media.

pros: EngenderHealth has been well-respected for a long time for the work that it does with women around the world. In general, work-life balance is good and many colleagues are smart and dedicated.
cons: Management, both the new senior leadership and management at lower levels, is increasingly dominated by ineffective egotists who show either a lack of understanding about what EH does and why, a lack of caring about what EH does and why, or both. The org has no clear direction. Staff who should be valued are leaving at an alarming rate. There is no trust or transparency at any level of the org. Benefits are being slashed with no rationale or warning. Organizational morale is at an all-time low.

pros: The rank and file at EngenderHealth are great people who work really hard and are committed to the work that EngenderHealth does.
cons: The new CEO has no executive leadership experience and she is driving the organization into the ground. She is delusional. She has surrounded herself with people who will just say yes to whatever she says (sound familiar?). She is mostly concerned with how she feels. If doing something will make her feel badly, then she does not want to do it, even if it means closing programs, people loosing jobs, support to programs being stopped, and people in resource poor suffering. At least she won't feel badly about a decision she has made.,

job_title: Knowledge Management Officer in Cebu City
pros: EH gives you a very enriching experience in each of its projects. The people are friendly, easy to talk to and very supportive.
cons:
*Meetings were a challenge because my work base is of another time zone. We had to deal with internet connectivity issues, time zones, and differing English accents. But these things could not be helped.

*Job was project-based with EH as implementing partner. I enjoyed every day of my job with EH. Sadly, our project ended and so did my job.

review_title: If you are considering a position here, don't do it
pros: There are truly no more pros to this organization. Everything is wiped away by the poor management.
cons: The morale here is awful, nearly all the staff has left or is leaving. The new CEO is a tyrant and her senior management team will jump as high as she asks them to. All former perks and camaraderie is lost. So many positions are open now, if you are considering applying to EngenderHealth, do not do it. You will regret your decision. This place is flailing.

pros: Amazing country offices with staff who have become like family. They continue to implement great programs, even as the CEO makes it increasingly difficult. Kind and technically strong junior and mid-level staff at HQ.
cons:
A burning dumpster fire of a once-great organization. The level of chaos the new CEO, Ulla Muller, has created in less than a year is astounding. If the goal was to dismantle the organization in the slowest, most callous, most corrupt way possible while causing as much pain and fear to employees around the globe... then mission accomplished. I won’t repeat all of what my amazing colleagues have voiced in previous Glassdoor posts, but will only say it’s all true and worse. 

The CEO and her complicit Executive Team pinch pennies from country programs and junior/ middle management staff while spending hundreds of thousands of dollars (that is not an exaggeration) of unrestricted funds on lawyers to strip her own employees of rights, consultants to teach her how to act like a human being, consultants to inform those consultants on how to talk about the fact that the CEO is a monster, and even computer forensic specialists to search employee laptops to see who is speaking ill of the Dear Leader. Ulla cares so deeply about these Glassdoor posts that she launched a campaign forcing staff to write positive posts (which no one could bring themselves to do), but still won’t acknowledge them of have an honest discussion about staff grievances. Anyone who asks valid questions in meetings is belittled. Anyone who questions her in private is let go, including some who tried to warn her that using the organization as her personal bank looks bad to donors. US-based colleagues are leaving as quickly as possible, even before the “restructure” was announced. Colleagues in country offices voice their displeasure and feelings of being disrespected, but Ulla is so neo-colonial she either doesn’t see it or  doesn’t care. The damage has been done. This field is small, and word travels fast. Ulla Muller has made a name for herself, and it’s not good. 

EngenderHealth may not survive Ulla Muller’s insane narcissism and nonsensical “strategic plan,” to the great detriment of the country programs that provide lifesaving work. However, to borrow from Ulla’s patronizing mantra which she states every time she makes an ill-informed decree, we are “brave and determined.” Ulla, please rest assured that the dedicated, passionate, technically trained EngenderHealth employees around the globe that you have demeaned and taken for granted are VERY brave, and also very well-connected. We are determined to ensure that all of the heartless and downright corrupt acts of Ulla Muller come to light. The only thing making me feel better as I watch the implosion of EngenderHealth is knowing that the rest of this field is watching too. Ulla Muller will have a hard time getting a new job in this field after she’s done destroying EngenderHealth, and it’s completely her own doing. 

At this point, we are spending our time consoling each other, protecting our colleagues as best we can from Executive Team, helping each other look for jobs, and fighting for the organization to stick to SOPs and respect HR contracts.

pros: The organization provides a strong benefits package and 401k. This is largely due to a well-established union within the organization that collectively bargains for the rights and benefits of its workers.
cons:
As my colleague mentioned in their March 21, 2018 post, don’t be fooled by the positive reviews written with boilerplate language - they are fraudulent reviews written for the executive leadership by absurdly overpaid consultants to recruit new employees in DC. 

After ousting an incompetent, authoritarian, and manipulative President, whom they hired, the Board took the reigns and decimated its technical and operational talent. Instead of engaging staff, who have expertise and experience in the SRHR sector, and owning missteps, they continued with the former President’s plan to re-structure and move the NY office to DC.

Prior to the President’s departure, an external consultant came onboard to interview staff across departments and recommend a new structure that would better support EngenderHealth’s strategic plan. At that point, the strategic plan was (and still is), a PowerPoint, filled with immeasurable objectives, antiquated jargon, and inspiring photographs. We were told the re-structure assessment would be a participatory process and an opportunity for staff to provide input.  Instead, three months later (post-President’s departure), the Board and VPs presented the new organogram (with no accompanying narrative or rationale) that eliminated many operational positions critical to the organization’s functioning – and there was no time for Q&A.

The rationale for the move (and the process by which it is being carried out) has never made any sense to staff. I can be sympathetic to lay-offs when there is a sound rationale and feasible plan in place, but leadership has never authentically communicated the logic behind their decisions. They continue to autocratically plow forward with hubris, treating those beneath them as insubordinate nuisances, rather than human beings with dignity or professionals who have relevant expertise and training in SRHR and who have committed their life’s work to social change and gender equality.

review_title: Open Letter to the Board of Directors
pros: This 70+ year old NGO had a track record of success and impact in the lives of women, girls, and families in 121 countries around the globe. This organization attracted best-in-class change-makers dedicated to its beneficiaries.
cons: Befuddled CEO, inept leadership, cripplingly low morale.

review_title: Do NOT be deceived by recent fake reviews - the org is imploding (and it is completely self-inflicted)
pros: I still do believe in the value of the work that this long-standing NGO performs. Unfortunately, as the past two years demonstrate, it has been difficult to impossible to focus productively on the work amidst the tangle of deception, vindictiveness, and utter incompetence demonstrated by the Board, and the "leadership" at headquarters (culminating in massive lay offs).
cons:
Let me begin by pointing out the the last few reviews on this site are blatantly fake and have been planted. The organization engages exorbitantly priced consultants to presumably in part craft these insulting, deceptive reviews as they try to salvage what they can of the organization's tattered reputation. These reviews are clearly timed with the organization's MASSIVE recruitment effort, as it seeks to essentially re-hire an entirely new HQ staff. There are 21 positions currently being advertised (and so far less than 10 staff who will remain - mostly the folks who were already in the D.C. office, promoted themselves into Executive Roles, and/or otherwise glorified their own titles).

Next, let's try to unpack why it is that they need an entirely new HQ.  It is still unclear what the move to Washington accomplishes. It has been said that it is to "have a seat at the table" - but EngenderHealth already HAD AN OFFICE IN WASHINGTON. And, what table?! The ousted CEO (Ulla Mueller) set these wheels in motion, and the Board/"leadership" had an opening when she was forced out to reverse course, or even to grow the Washington office organically through hiring as it reduced the size of the office in NY.  Yet, they went full steam ahead with the plan (without a plan). 

The result: Only TWO NY-based staff (who were not Executive Team members or fully funded on a global project) accepted their offers to stay with this company. There is a reason for this, and it speaks volumes. (It is also how we know that the last two reviews are fake.) Also, contrary to what is said in Jan. 23 review about the "Board compensating those who chose to move to D.C." what they are actually doing is reimbursing moving expenses up to a certain amount, which seems only fair given the completely radical change in the terms of employment. The sad truth is that employees who remain with EngenderHealth's new HQ is that they will actually be paid LESS than they are currently. The company has extended the official working day by one hour per day (meaning that employees will be expected to work five extra hours a week, a whopping 20 extra hours a month) - FOR THE EXACT SAME SALARY.  They have also barred telecommuting, one of the main "benefits" that have been touted in previous reviews over the years. Salaries for all new hires will be REDUCED by 8% over previous salary scales in the new Washington D.C. salary structure (something all job seekers should be cognizant of). 

The irony and cynicism of an organization supposedly committed to  “women and girls first” while instituting such family unfriendly policies should not be lost on anyone. They talk about "delivering on their central mission" in their strategic plan (which is still being tinkered with) but can't even deliver on it at home.

job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: I really enjoyed my experience at EngenderHealth. Had a great supervisor and lots of opportunities to take on new responsibilities. Got to travel the world doing work I believed in.
cons: The number of staff based in the US has dropped as funding for EngenderHealth's funding declines. They used to have a unique niche (long-acting and permanent methods of family planning, fistula care, gender), but other organizations are now encroaching on that space.

review_title: Sad and alarming state of decline
pros:
If I wrote this review just 6 months ago, this section would look very different. Today I’m hard-pressed to identify any Pros beyond this: My colleagues are talented, intelligent, kind, mission-oriented. They are the organization's best assets though you would not know it from the actions of senior leadership in the last 6 months.

I love this organization and what it stands for. I’m sad to witness its slow demise owing to an inexperienced new CEO and the team of Yes People she has staffed around her. There are eerie parallels with the Titanic. Everyone is scrambling to jump ship before the inevitable happens.
cons:
Over the last 6 months the work environment at EngenderHealth has gone from being positive, collegial, family friendly, and mission-focused to being poisonous and distressing on an emotional and professional level. Every other day there are new departures, and dismissals, of beloved staff. Once-progressive policies on telework/flex (a lifeline for those with young children) are disappearing under increasingly autocratic management policies. It is only a matter of time before all the talent has been drained from the organization. It is hugely demoralizing and alarming. 

The fact that there is pervasive dissatisfaction with and mistrust of the senior leadership across all Divisions and Teams is so telling. There is a serious lack of transparency or communication from the senior ranks. The new CEO is not consultative, even vindictive toward those who challenge her and they were subsequently shown the door. It is a disturbing pattern of behavior. The CEO may have strong programmatic experience but she has a conspicuous deficit in executive leadership skills and does not rely on the counsel of others to compensate for this shortcoming. She lacks vision and is not collegial with staff, bordering on arrogant, which sets a toxic tone for organizational culture that is antithetical to EngenderHealth's positive, charitable mission.

People are turning to Glassdoor.com to express their concerns for the future of this organization because there are literally no avenues for open dialogue within the organization without fear for job security. As it stands today, EngenderHealth is not a friendly or productive place to work or grow as a professional. If you're considering applying for a job here, I urge you to wait another 3-5 years (if it’s still afloat) or until there is CEO turnover. If not you will find yourself among a disenfranchised group of colleagues who are deeply dissatisfied on a daily basis and desperately searching for exit strategies.

review_title: Great - very committed people & great mission
pros: I've had a great experience at EngenderHealth.  Friendly, committed people and the mission represents exactly what I am most passionate about.
cons: The organization has gone through a lot of change in recent years and I expect that is influencing some of the more critical reviews-- but my experience has been very positive.

pros:
great mission
good benefits package
long history in field
cons:
Complete lack of management - top level and middle level
Management staff are ego maniacs that explicitly let you know that they don't want feedback or suggestions
Dreary office
Sexism in the office
Managers play favorites
No acknowledgment of work whatsoever 
No support staff
Expectation to work ridiculous hours
Old staff want to work using old ways - not open to new ideas
No one is open to feedback.  If you give feedback you are shunned.
No access to research - yet they call themselves science-based

review_title: Organization with potential but sub optimal use of capacity
pros: Intellectual capital, Standard policies and protocols, expertise in reproductive health
cons: Limited area of functioning, slow adaptability to changing dynamics of public health.

review_title: The titanic is sinking so get your lifeboat ready
pros: Competitive salary, great vacation, exceptional field staff, great benefits and 40 hour work weeks.
cons: The organization is falling apart due to poor senior management and a change in the funding landscape. Ninety percent of the staff are looking for new opportunities and anyone who isn't should start as the organization at HQ is shrinking. Senior leadership is clueless and they are generally only looking out for themselves and don't care about the company's future as they're all just planning for retirement.

pros: Salary, benefits, exposure in terms of new challenges at work. Infact, I was shaped  by this organization and cannot be thankful enough.
cons: Funding constraint which is a normal thing in NGOs.

review_title: I have learned a lot from this organisation
pros: Good employer who give their employees the best opportunities and a platform to learn. They are always there to assist employees.
cons: The employment condition because I am employed on a contract basis. I would be glad if I was employed on a permanent basis.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: EngenderHealth has strong name recognition and an important mission, as well as a decent salary for a non-profit organization; however, these can only take you so far...
cons: Atrocious management--the worst I've ever experienced...EngenderHealth (and its HR department) protects its incompetent managers at the expense of lower-level staffers. Managers pay lip service to "open communication" while creating a toxic work environment. Nitpicking  and micromanagement don't even begin to describe their management style. STAY AWAY if you have any other options.

review_title: M&E Officer at The Stop Malaria Project in Uganda
job_title: Monitoring and Evaluation Officer in Kampala
pros: They are globally the leading not for profit organizations in the world. The work environment is very good as people feel proud to be part. They offer a good platform where I can learn more because offer full support in both career development and professional front.
cons: Nothing really in particular this is because I have not heard anything wrong about them.

pros: long track record of life-changing work worldwide; devoted staff in the field and up through middle management in the US; several knowledgeable and capable board members
cons: uniformed and tone-deaf board leadership; misguided US senior management with several not competent to hold their positions; recent train wreck of a CEO

pros:
good mission
some key leaders with core values
great country staff
cons:
Things may have changed with all the downsizing, butmorale was low and the main challenges included:
middle management did not listen to staff
tension between field staff and HQ
limited connection to UN
limited growth and too project dependent for funding

pros: The benefits and staff that worked at the now closed NY offices were both great. But please note that who comprised the NY staff is around 98%  different now that the org relocated to D.C.
cons: All the recent "positive" reviews are totally fake. I was motivated to write this review because I want the team writing those reviews to know that all former EngenderHealth staff are on to their game.

pros: An employee friendly place to work; management open to new ideas;  professional and committed workforce; very strong in technical areas of expertise; lots of opportunity to learn and grow.
cons: Need to be more aggressive and focused on expanding the portfolio within the countries we operate.

review_title: Not a good place for young people looking for growth
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Friendly/dedicated staff, laid back work environment
cons: Low pay, a lot of boring work, no growth for young people. Smart employees holding master's degree are just admin assistants.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Competitive salary with excellent benefits; opportunities for professional development and travel to field offices; work among intelligent, passionate and motivated colleagues; can rely on coworkers when projects are difficult
cons: No tuition reimbursement provided; nothing else to add

pros: Committed staff, good, friendly environment. Staff interested in their work.
cons: It is the never ending changing organization, not for the best. Lack of leadership, of a clear path forward. No transparency.

pros: There used to be plenty, but they're gone now.
cons: The Board made a disastrous choice in the new CEO, who has both destroyed the organization's prospects for future funding and created a toxic work environment. Instead of listening to feedback and trying to work productively, the Board and their new CEO have dug their heels in to stay the course.

job_title: Regional Representative in Dar es Salaam, Dar es Salaam
pros: IT is great organization that focuses on women and girls
cons: It is currently operating in few countries

review_title: Will be out of business soon
pros: Competitive salaries, great benefits, good pto.
cons:
- As others have said, this organization is falling apart and management is watching it happen. They are too busy trying to bust a union that 1/3 of employees are members of in order to spend time working on bettering their programming. 

- The technical experts in the organization can be counted on one hand.

review_title: Look elsewhere for a rewarding career
pros: Flexible work schedules/telecommuting allowed. Some staff extremely smart and pleasant to work with.
cons: Very poor sr. leadership and management who lack interest in latest evidence or innovations. No mentorship or cultivation of junior or middle-level staff. Internal structural barriers to collaboration among staff/teams. Internal dissent and/or critique of systems or technical approaches (in favor of group discussion/problem solving) is routinely discouraged.

pros: All the good things have been taken away. Any culture/perks have been destroyed.

New CEO, huge turnover
Be careful of what you say or you'll be punished.

cons: Work seems to me is one sided. There is no extra challenges for further improvement.
